article.para: This is a very simple shortest path routing daemon. It was written to replace ospfd in the &wleiden; network. Sometimes assumptions are made about the network that hold for &wleiden;, but may not for other networks. Those cases are marked and, if possible, alternative implementations provided.

System requirements are &freebsd; 5.0 or 5.3. Other versions may work, but haven't been tested at all. A port to other systems would be fairly easy in that all unportable code is isolated in one relatively small source file.

The main body of code is written in &ocaml;. For changes other than porting the bit of C code that handles interaction with the kernel, you would need to know &ocaml; (something I would highly recommend).

listitem.para: UDP based. No firmware-confusing multi- or broadcasts.
No per-node configuration.
Uses spanning trees, so no count-to-infinity.
Specific wireless hacks to speed up convergence and route propagation.
Protection against malicious packets and replaying of legitimate packets.

section.title: Auto-configuration
section.para:
If your network has both a well-defined routable range
For &wleiden;, this is 172.16.0.0/12.
and well-defined interlink netmasks (say, anything narrower than a /29), the daemon will be able to do the right thing automatically. Relevant tunables are Common.min_routable, Common.max_routable and Common.interlink_netmask.

warning.para: Do not set Common.interlink_netmask too wide. The daemon will consider all addresses in the interlink subnet other than its own possible neighbors. It will allocate resources for them and spend time trying to reach its peers on those addresses. Keep your interlinks as narrow as possible.

section.para: If your network does not have such clearly recognizable interlinks, you would have to hack in a configuration file scheme into lvrouted.read_config. An older version of the source tree may help. Revision 2957 of &root; is the last version that did work with a config file.

section.title: Spanning trees
section.para: This branch uses spanning trees to achieve shortest-path routing without cycles. A node knows its local addresses and will receive the spanning trees of its neighbors. It can then merge these pieces of information into a spanning tree for the node plus a routing table by simply traversing the trees breadth-first. The new spanning tree is sent to the neighbors and the route table is uploaded to the kernel.

Note that while "spanning tree" and "network" may conjure up images of a single spanning tree for the network that leaves many links unused, this is not the case here. Every node has a spanning tree of its own, and they will all be different.

section.title: Wireless hacks
section.para:
The daemon tries to know quickly if a client has lost (or gained) association or association has been lost (gained) with a master. Media state and arp tables are monitored to figure out what neighbors became (un)reachable, rather than waiting for the relatively long neighbor timeout
A haven't-heard-from-X-for-so-long-it-must-be-dead timeout.
to occur.
When such events are detected, a new spanning tree and new route table are produced immediately and sent around.

section.title: Security
section.para:
A &wleiden; assumption is that machines can trust eachother, that administrative connections to those machines are trusted (ssh). Users can not be trusted, since it's an open network. Attackers may try to get the daemon to crash, or try to muck up routing in the network by feeding nodes faulty or old data
A patch is ready to be deployed to hide interlink SSIDs. This will make it more difficult for an attacker, but certainly not impossible as most of the node configurations live in a publically accessible &svn; repository.
.

Because nodes can trust eachother, all that is needed is that they be able to verify that packets sent to them are from a legitimate node. A simple secret key scheme would be able to do that. The problem of distributing the secret keys safely is no problem here because administrative connections are secure.

A packet consists of a hash, a sequence number and the serialized spanning tree. The hash is SHA1 of the concatenation of the secret key, the sequence number and the serialized tree. An attacker won't know the secret key and will not be able to produce a valid hash.

The sequence number is an increasing number. A node will keep track of the sequence numbers it receives from its neighbors, and will only accept packets with a higher sequence number. Currently, the sequence number is simply the unix timestamp. The sequence number is part of the hash, so an attacker cannot change it without invalidating the hash. This solves replay attacks with (once) legitimate packets.

A node will initialize the structures for its neighbors with the lowest possible timestamp. This leaves a hole where an attacker can replay old packets. This hole closes once the real neighbor sends its first packet and the node updates the timestamp in the neighbor structure to beyond what the attacker can have captured. So be it, that's a hole small enough for me not to care.

warning.para: This does pose a problem with machines that cannot keep time in their CMOSs, like many old donated machines. If you have such machines, either do not correct their time at all, or start the routing daemon after correcting their time (like with ntpdate).

If you first start the routing daemon and then correct the time, the following will happen. Unix timestamps are 32bit unsigned integers, while &ocaml; integers are 31bit signed. The current Unix timestamp is large enough to wrap around into a a large negative &ocaml; integer. Clocks that cannot keep time are usually initialized to 1980, which is not large enough to wrap around, so that is a large positive &ocaml; integer. If the daemon manages to get a packet out before the time correction, its neighbors will remember that timestamp. After the time correction, packets will have the very large negative sequence number and will be rejected. The node will be ignored by its neighbors for over twenty years. You'd have to restart the daemon on all neighbors to fix this.

section.title: Tree marshaling
section.para: Marshalling trees was done using &ocaml;'s generic Marshal module at first. This is completely network agnostic (even data structure agnostic, it will serialize any data structure you pass it) and took just over eight bytes per tree node.

Recently, custom marshaling code was added. This assumes the 172.16.0.0/12 range. For other ranges, either the original code must be used by setting the Common.use_own_marshaller to false, or the marshaling code must be adapted.

The idea behind the custom marshaller is that to store a node, it is enough to store the node contents (the address in this case) and the number of children. Now, a part of the address will be fixed (the first twelve bits for &wleiden;) and can be used to store the number of children. That gives four bytes per tree node, versus just over eight for the generic &ocaml; marshaller.
Three bytes per tree node was almost possible, but that would leave four bits for the number of children. &wleiden; either already has nodes with more than sixteen ranges or will conceivably get them eventually.

The code that would need adapting for other ranges is in tree_to_string_rec() and string_to_tree_rec() in lowlevel_c.c. As this involves navigating &ocaml; data structures, you may want to read the manual on interfacing with C.

section.title: Options
section.para: There are a lot of tunable options defined in Common.ml.

listitem.para: port: The UDP port to listen on and send to.
alarm_timeout: The number of seconds between each call to the alarm handler. The alarm handler checks for interesting events and will broadcast to neighbors if necessary.

bcast_interval: Threshold number of seconds between sending spanning trees to neighbors. If the alarm handler sees it's been more than this number of seconds since the last broadcast, it will start sending.
compress_data: Boolean indicating whether or not to bzip2 the packets. NOT YET TESTED IN PRODUCTION and the code in lowlevel_c.c will abort until it has been properly tested.
real_route_updates: Boolean indicating whether or not to present the routing updates to the kernel.
interlink_netmask: The netmask that's just narrow enough to be an interlink subnet. For &wleiden; this is 28.
iface_assoc_update: A float indicating the number of seconds the information about interface associations is valid. Longer than this means the kernel gets asked again.
arptables_update_every: The number of seconds the ARP information retreived from the kernel stays valid.
secret: The secret key to sign packets with. If this is empty, no hashing is done.
foreground: Boolean indicating whether or not to remain in the foreground or become a daemon.
use_syslog: Boolean indicating whether or not to log to syslog. If false and the log level is set, the log will go to /tmp/lvrouted.log.
min_mask: The widest netmask Route.aggregate can produce. This should be your subnet width.

min_routable and max_routable: The boundaries of the routable range. These are inclusive and exclusive respectively. For &wleiden; this is 172.16.0.0 and 172.31.255.0. The 172.31.255.0/24 is a net of virtual addresses for us and is not routable.
own_marshaller: Boolean indicating whether or not to use the &wleiden; specific serializing code. If false, the standard &ocaml; Marshal module will be used.
tmpdir: Where to dump debug files.

row.entry: Log.loglevel, the minimum severity for a message to be logged. Check Log.ml for the levels.
Re-examine interface addresses. If you add a node to the network, simply kill -HUP the daemon on its neighbors and they will find the newly added interlink range.
